body: An express subway train on the way to Manhattan from Kennedy International Airport was derailed in Brooklyn last night by vandals, and although none of the 20 passengers and crew were hurt, service was interrupted on parts of the A line for about an hour, the Transit Authority said. Robert Huber, a spokesman for the authority, said the three-car
title: THE CITY; Vandals Derail 'Train to the Plane'

title: CITY VOTE FOR TOP STATE OFFICES BY ASSEMBLY DISTRICTS; DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR GOVERNOR

body: New York City's budget, shaped largely in private by municipal officials, got its first public hearings yesterday and the reception was mostly negative. The problems facing young, old, handicapped and poor people, rising crime and arson rates, rundown parks and crumbling highways, bridges and sewers were the main topics as the Board of Estimate and
title: CITY BUDGET IS CRITICIZED AT 2 HEARINGS

body: Four hundred gravediggers and groundskeepers went on strike yesterday at 12 nonsectarian cemeteries in the metropolitan area. Sam Cimaglia, president of Local 365 of the Service Employees International Union, said it was a selective strike that would affect only about 60 burials a day. But he warned that the walkout might be expanded next week to
title: CEMETERY UNION CALLS STRIKE AT 12 SITES IN NEW YORK AREA

body: Negotiations between the management of 70 cemeteries in the metropolitan area and a union of 1,800 workers broke down last night over the issue of arbitration, and a selective strike was called for 7 A.M. today. The union said five cemeteries in Queens would be struck: Lutheran in Middle Village, Maple Grove in Kew Gardens, St. Michael's in
title: THE CITY; Cemetery Workers Call Strike Today
